climbs.name: Yellow Brick Road
climbs.fa: Michael Gladkin, Javier García, Manny Rangel

content.description: Face route with a variety of moves.
content.protection: 8 bolts with two bolts at the top.
content.location: About 50 feet to the right of Broken Arrow/Tourist Treat

content.description: Ascend left side of the face.  The first move is the hardest.
content.location: West-facing route, just to the left of Lacerated legs, on the same face.

content.description: Follow crack/chimney up the face.  Bypass the roof near the top by going right.
content.protection: Shares anchor with Broken Arrow.  4 bolts, cams, nuts.
content.location: 30 feet to the right of Geronimo.

content.description:
The bolted route climbs up the left side of the face, with steady climbing most of the route.  The crux is about 80% of the way up where the climber steps back out onto the face above an overhang.

 Frankly, the entire face is quite climbable, all the way up.
content.protection: 14 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.  A 70m rope is recommended.  You will need a second rope to get down if you want to lead it.
content.location: Below Trimmed Bush and Lacerated Legs.  The anchors are accessible from the base of Lacerated Legs.

content.description: This route ascends the the NW side of the pillar.  The start of the bolted route consists of pulling over a slight bulge on the north side of the pillar.
content.protection: Bolts, with a two bolt anchor set back from the edge.
content.location: About 100 yards south of Geronimo.  Look for a semi-detached pillar; you will need to hop across to access the anchors.

content.description: Big, big holds up a vertical face.This would be an ideal first-timer route.
The first bolt is rather high for someone who is climbing at this grade.  Likewise for the runout after the last bolt.  This route is accessible from either the bottom or the top.
content.location: To the right of trimmed bush, going up the same face.

content.description: Winding your way up this two pitch arete is a great day out. The views alone are worth it. The new anchors make the rappel and semi-hangibg belay memorable.
content.protection: 17 bolts or so for one pitch or
content.location: Hike up a good trail that is cairned well for an hour or so to the cattle tank just below the Leap edge. Turn right and follow cairns near the top. Other climbs are sprouting cairns too on the way to Geronimo. Keep working your way along the edge (roughly) until you're above the huge fin.

content.description: Face climb .  You will find yourself searching quite a bit to the left or right of the bolt line for good hands.  The crux is just after the first bolt where one must pull over a bulge (or go around).  The middle third of the climb is substantially easier than the beginning or the end.
content.protection: 8 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. An additional set of bolts set back from the edge facilitate a comfy top belay.  If you top rope this route, you will want to put in some quick draws on the way down, as the route meanders a bit.
content.location: North facing route in an alcove, just around the corner from yellow brick road.

content.description: I put this route up after I mended from a FX wrist. It was worth the effort An unusual bone white face of rhyolite just right of Geronimo's arete, this line shoots up thin face and even a crack move or two.
content.protection: 15 bolts going to 2 rappel rings plus 2 bolts set back a bit for a top belay.  Shares anchors with Tourist Treat.
content.location: From Geronimo it's the next route south on the cliff. You can find the anchors but stay tied in if you want to reach the exposed anchor.

content.description: This iconic rhyolite cliff band is immense. It will become a great resource after RCM completes the land swap. The management plan has been approved and climbing is a recognized activity here.
